content.description: Sit down start on near the south end of the east face.  Climb to a couple of flat ledges, move your feet up and dyno to the lip. (Moving to higher ledges and throwing for the lip with just one hand is a V2.)
content.location: Look for the obvious, chalked-up slopey side-pull under the overhang.

content.description: Start to the right of the obvious traverse, down low under the left side of the small roof. There should be two pockets for hands and a small flake for a foot. Throw a hand up around the roof to the sharp jugs, hook a foot, and cross left to a decent crimp before topping out on jugs. The crux is the starting move.
Avoiding the jugs on the lip, traverse the boulder from left to right on the overhanging east face.

Traverse from the far SW pocket following the crack to the arete above the daunting rock before the dropoff. Continue to the pockets at the same level around it. Finish by topping out at the rigid jugs above after the arete where the “

dyno route

” exists.
content.location: Start at the farthest west pocket, and traverse right to the arete. Heel hook around it to the next pockets, and finish topping out above at the rigid jugs at the roof.

content.description:
I believe on Monday (11/19/18) my buddy, Ryan Mike, and I put up a new line in the area. It is a slightly contrived traverse problem, but the moves are very high quality. You start down below the bulge on two underclings, and make a strenuous first move to a right-hand slot. Move your feet out right, and bump through the slots. Get set up for a tough move out left to a sub-par crimp, then make a huge cross move (multiple betas work here) to the crux hold, a garbage right-hand crimp with a small thumb catch. From here, either use 6 foot beta to bump into the sloper above the right-hand hold, or lock off the right hand, get a high left foot, and slap that thing with your left. Finally, get your left hand to the final jug (don't dab on the rock!), and top out far left.

If this is not a first ascent, please feel free to comment down below, and change the info! I had a start hold break on me, and some of the other holds had literally 0 chalk on them, so we believe it is!
content.protection: A pad on top of the rock for the crux. You might want a pad behind it too, I would hit the rock then roll onto the ground sometimes. 1 pad to work on this problem is fine, 2 for sending is best!
